ns:appellation.ns:name: Linewath, Carrock Fell Hut Circle, Cairnfield, Caldbeck

ns:description.ns:full:
Possible hut circles (round houses indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) and cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Possible settlement area consisting of cairns, probable hut circles, between Linewath and Stone Ends Farm (S1361). A saucer-shaped depression (possible hut circle) excavated 1932 near the Black Beck where it approaches Linewath Farm. Consisted of a sunken pit 5 1/2 ft in diam, 3 ft deep with an entrance passage. No dating evidence (S1910 p 110-13 map, plan and sections). Two other sites excavated 1937 thought to be huts. See article 'Excavations in Carrock' in the 1950 volume of C&WAAS (S1909 p. 201). These cairns are difficult to locate and can be confused with mining debris. Black Beck is listed as an extensive Bronze Age settlement by Challis and Harding (S1055 p. 43). For details of archaeological investigation at this site see the NMR excavation index 645819, 645820 (S1347). See also SMR 3763, 5925, 8395. SEE SMR 9698 on CLAU print-out. The site is visible on aerial photographs from The University of Manchester (S918) and J K S St Joseph (S920) collections.

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Some of these have possible cists (generally rectangular structure normally used for burial purposes, and formed from stone slabs set on edge, and covered by one or more horizontal slabs or capstones. Cists may be built on the surface or sunk into the ground).

Ten cairns and one stone heap located on a steep-sided ridge (S2686). All except one are said to be 4.6 - 6.1 m in diam. The exception was 9.8 m. Of those excavated nothing was found, "but hollow centres in many" (S1939 - site no. 362). See article 'Excavations above Milkingstead in Eskdale' in the 1928 volume of C&WAAS (S1967 p. 149-151). See the NAS 1975 gazetteer (S1323). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S1069). For details of excavation at this site see the NMR excavation index 629376 (S1347).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) including a ring cairn (a low, wide, circular ring or bank of stones surrounding an open, roughly circular area which is (or was initially) free of cairn material. The inner and outer faces of the bank may be kerbed) of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32833. See associated HERs 1488, 1489, 7690, 7878, 31040, 31041, 31042, 31043, 31051, 31049, and 31050.

Site identified from vertical aerial photographs taken as part of the CLAU VAP Project in 1983 and field observation undertaken 10 May 1983. The site is composed of c.30 cairns, c. 0.5m av. Diam. 2 are saucer-shaped. A large cairn measuring c.0.75m high, 15m diam., constructed of small stones, is situated on a knoll. A stone-lined rectangular depression measures c.3m x 0.5m, 0.3m deep. Enclosures identified from VAPs as darker areas within the vegetation were not located on the ground. A lot of vehicle tracks in the vicinity threaten the site. For other cairnfields in the area see HERs 1488, 1489, 7690 and 7878 (S1069). Also see article 'Plotting of Archaeological Sites from Vertical Aerial Photographs: An Interim Report' by V.E. Turner in the 1984 volume of C&WAAS (S1868 p. 270-274). The CLAU Survey of Bootle Fell in 1987 identified a large number of cairns within this area, bounded to the north by a substantial bog. On the northern side of Oldclose Gill there is a group of 4 ring features in varying states of preservation (see HERs 31040, 31041, 31042, 31043). The excavation of one of these showed it to have been deliberately constructed, with larger stones on the inner and outer edges, and demonstrated that it was not a disturbed round cairn. The site was interpreted by the excavator as a ring cairn. The cairns to the south are well scattered and are consistent with stone clearance activity. The exception is a site at SD1298489128), which is a large, prominent cairn on top of a natural hillock. It is probably a funerary cairn now HER 31051, other prominent cairns are HER 31049 and 31050 (S1917). The site is now included within an extensive area of scheduling. See scheduling for details (S904, S905). Also see article 'Excavations at Birrel Sike, near Low Prior Scales, Calder Valley' in the 1982 volume of C&WAAS (S1870 p. 7-27).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Pike Howe Prehistoric Cairnfield and Associated Field System 320m SW of High Ground

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary) and lengths of wall of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32881.

A group of 40-50 cairns and remains of old walls. According to George & Crawford this is possibly an extension of the cairnfield noted as HER 1424 from which it is divided only by the modern road and related quarry pits (S1116). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 366 (S1939). Extending along the south slope of Pike How either side of the road from Eskdale to Ulpha are an enclosure, three lengths of walling and 148 small cairns including both round and long cairns. The enclosure and other walls survive to only one course of boulders in height. The west side of the group is sharply defined by a concentration of small cairns and on the north the watershed forms the approximate limit. Within the group as a whole are several void areas of ground similar to those occupied by cairns. Possibly the construction of the road has resulted in the destruction of some cairns close to the roadside. See article 'Settlements and Cairns on Birkby and Birker Fells' by Leech in the 1983 volume of C&WAAS (S1869 p. 18). J. Cherry in his article in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS recorded 100 cairns in sites for HERs 1424 and 1425 (S2085 p. 9). However, detailed survey conducted by CLAU in 1982 has recorded 199 (S1065). The site can be seen on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). Note the scheduled area is split into 3 land parcels. The monument includes Pike How prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system 320m south west of High Ground. It is located along the southern slopes of Pike How and extends both east and west of the Ulpha-Eskdale minor road, and north and south of the access road to High Ground and Birkerthwaite. The monument represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and is sub-divided into three separate areas of protection. The prehistoric cairnfield is centered at approximately SD16959775 and consists of over 160 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring up to 0.8m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.9m to 6.75m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 3.2m to 10.1m long by 1.8m to 7.9m wide. A field system associated with the cairnfield consists of a curvilinear enclosure sub-divided by traces of a central stone bank situated to the west of the Ulpha-Eskdale road at approximately SD17019775. The walls of the enclosure are discontinuous and it may have been damaged by construction of the road. On the east side of the Ulpha-Eskdale road a 70m length of stone bank or wall may originally have formed part of this enclosure. However, a broad cairn-free area immediately south of this wall suggests it originally functioned as a field boundary. Two other short lengths of stone wall are located towards the north west and north east sides of the cairnfield. Elsewhere within the cairnfield a number of other cairn-free areas may indicate the site of former fields (S905). Site visited on the 30/11/2011 (images HER_1425#1). Site is in reasonable condition (S5197).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehist Enclosure/Related Sites E of Whillan Beck, Eskdale

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and an enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier) containing a hut circle (a round house indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 23695.

The monument includes a prehistoric enclosure which contains a hut circle and a cairnfield lying predominantly to the east and west of the enclosure. It is located on a sloping fellside at the E end of a large area of open moorland known as Burnmoor which contains an abundance of prehistoric remains. The enclosure is sub-oval in shape and is identified as a stock pen. It is entered from the SW and measures approx 17m x 8m internally with a boundary wall of drystone construction three courses high and up to 2.5m wide. The SE arm of the boundary wall projects southwards beyond the entrance in two separate lengths for a further 26m. The NW arm of the boundary wall widens out at the entrance to accommodate a small hut circle about 4m in diam which is also entered from the SW. A short distance to the W of the enclosure, and forming part of the cairnfield, are two sub-circular cairns. They are both 0.2m high and measure 6.5m x 4.1m and 4.8m x 3.6m. Further to the W is a group of eight cairns most of which are round in shape and measure between 2.9m-5m in diam, while to the E of the enclosure there is a more dispersed group of 13 cairns, again round in shape, ranging from 2m-4m in diam. Among this eastern group there is a low drystone wall measuring 14.6m long x 2m wide and up to 0.5m high which is aligned WSW-ENE; this is interpreted as a field wall associated with the cairnfield. The monument survives well. It contains a developed type of cairnfield; that is one where the land has been subjected to initial land clearance and then utilised further - in this case by the construction of an enclosure and a hut circle. It contrasts markedly with the primary typs of cairnfield found elsewhere on Burnmoor and illustrates well differing prehistoric land management strategies. The monument lies close to other prehistoric monuments on Burnmoor and this indicates the importance of this area in prehistoric times. Scheduling includes a 2 metre boundary around the archaeological features, considered to be essential for the monument's support and preservation (S905). A cairnfield and enclosure identified during the CLAU 1984 Survey of Burnmoor. The enclosure is in poor condition, with ill-defined walls of small to medium stones, loose and protruding from the turf. The walls are up to 3 courses high. The size of the area was increased as 4 cairns were located during survey, just south of the main group (S1914). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Recordm from the sources given above (S2873). Included in Regional Archaeological Audit (S5350).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield 420m SE of the Triangulation Pillar on Rough Crag

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) containing two long and 43 round cairns (monuments featuring a bank or mound constructed primarily of stone) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32880.

This is an extensive cairnfield of ca 100 cairns. One extremity is marked by the remains of an early enclosure. Several of the cairns show signs of excavation. One measuring 2.8 m x 3.5 m was entirely removed in 1961 and the material sieved. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 8) Also see note in the 1964 volume of C&WAAS regarding the excavation undertaken by Cherry and Fletcher in 1961 (S2211 p. 373). The site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 369 (S1939). According to George & Crawford the only find was a flint flake (S1116 p. 48). Also see HER 1425. This cairnfield contains 2 long cairns and 43 round cairns. It is separated from HER 1425 by a 200m stretch, where no cairns were recorded. HER 1425 contains an enclosure, cairns and lengths of wall. The site was included in a survey of Birkby and Birker Fells by CLAU in 1982 (S1065). Also see article 'Settlements and Groups of Small Cairns on Birkby and Birker Fells' by Leech in the 1983 volume of C&WAAS for site location and details (S1869 p. 16). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield located on the southern slopes of Rough Crag 420m south east of the summit. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 40 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high which are scattered in two distinct groups separated by a flatter area of ground. The circular cairns measure between 1.7m to 5m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 5.6m to 7.8m long by 3.4m wide. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5000 years and show evidence of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. The clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield 570m SW of Barnscar Settlement

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32859.

A small, compact group of non-prominent cairns on a gentle to moderate, uniform slope which drops sharply on the western side into a stream gully; the western edge of the cairnfield is defined by the break of slope. There is a thick, matt grass vegetation cover in the area which obscures the cairns, hence they have only occasional stones protruding and are ill -defined. There are no significant cairn alignments and it appears to be a genuine, small, primary type of cairnfield (S1920). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield located on gently-sloping ground 570m south west of Barnscar settlement. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes ten oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 3m to 5.3m long by 2.8m to 4.9m wide and up to 0.4m high. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5,000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. The clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000BC (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield 660m NE of Barnscar Settlement

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) consisting of clearance cairns (irregularly constructed, generally unstructured, mounds of stones, often circular, and normally a by product of field clearance for agricultural purposes) and banks (linear or curvilinear construction of earth, turf and stone, often, but not always accompanied by a ditch) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32866.

The cairnfield is divided into two halves by a bank alignment, which is ill-defined and may represent the line of a boundary. The bank is fairly regular but not particularly prominent and is ill-defined in places. To the north of the bank the terrain is fairly undulating, it is generally moderately sloped however there are steep scarp slopes separating small natural, irregular terraces. At the bottom there is a distinct hollow, containing cairns, which is reminiscent of a nivation hollow. 2 cairns are on a small natural terrace above the hollow. The main part of the cairnfield at the eastern end is on a more uniform, gentle to moderate sloped terrain. To the west of the cairnfield is a localised mire. The cairns at the western end of the cairnfield are generally small, low-lying and ill-defined, whereas the main part of the group, at the eastern end, are fairly well-defined, large and prominent. There is a very prominent, three-sided bank at SD1375596327, with a regular width. There is no evidence of a western side and it does not display any evidence of internal terracing. The cairn at SD1380696363 is abnormally large and prominent and has a bield set into its southern side. Although the distribution of the cairns is limited in places by the local topography, in other places it is essentially random. There is a small group of cairns at the bottom of a break of slope on the southern side of bank.The cairns are on a relatively gentle slope but to the south of the cairn group there is a further break of slope which drops down to an extensive mire; hence this group is on a natural terrace. The cairns have a fairly compact, essentially random distribution. They are significantly smaller than those to the north of the bank alignment. They are generally ill-defined but slightly prominent in places (S1920). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield located on the undulating, moderate slope of a small spur on unenclosed land 660m north east of Barnscar settlement. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes a small number of stone banks and approximately 40 oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 2m to 8m long by lm to 5.6m wide and up to 0.5m high. Towards the south eastern side of the cairnfield there is a stone bank aligned north east-south west; the cairns on the south east side of this bank are generally smaller than those on the north west side of the bank, suggesting that this bank may once have formed a boundary. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were soon replaced by extensive grassland. This clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield 850m North West of Woodend Bridge, Eskdale

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of two cairnfields (groups of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument nos. 32885/6. See also HER 5350.

The site was identified from the 1983 CLAU digital data and seems to consist of 2 cairnfieds, the eastern one is centred at SD17230 96850 and the western at SD16680 96770. There is no text information that corresponds to this digital data, therefore further details are impossible to give (S1065). The monument includes the prehistoric cairnfield located on the southern slopes of The Seat 850m north west of Woodend Bridge. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 70 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.5m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.4m to 4.3m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 3m to 6.2m long by 1.9m to 4.4m wide (S905). Note: The scheduling only appears to cover the easternmost cairnfield as mentioned above; the other appears to be SAM 32886, HER 5350. The site appears to be the same as HER 5350. See that HER record for more details.

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield Immediately South of Birkerthwaite

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32894.

There is a small cairnfield situated on the banks of Highford Beck. The exact number is hard to determine due to the presence of spoil heaps from local quarries (S1361). See the article 'Cairns in the Birker and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 9). The site is also included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 368 (S1939) and George & Crawford's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 49). The area of the cairnfield has been enlarged after receiving digital data from the LUAU 1982/3 survey of Birkby and Birker Fell. There is no further information on the cairns presently available (S1065). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, located on relatively flat ground immediately south of Birkerthwaite. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 30 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 1.5m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.7m and 4.7m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 2.6m and 14.7m long by 1.7m to 5.6m wide. All modern field boundaries and gateposts are excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath these features is included (S905). Site visited on the 30/11/2011. Site is well managed, images HER_1246#1-4 were taken during this visit (S5197).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield and Associated Field System 730m ENE of Birkerthwaite

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and associated field system of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32890.

On the N side of Smallstone Beck is a group of 21 circular cairns ca 4.6 to 9.2 m in diameter. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 9). Also see the Report of the Committee for Prehistoric Studies 1936 in the 1937 volume of C&WAAS (S2048 p. 101) and the C&WAAS Regional Group Report by Hyam (S2003 p. 18). According to NAS Gazetteer there are also traces of a field system (S1323). The site is also included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 364 (S1939). The CLAU digital data shows a group of cairns and walls, possibly enclosures around this grid ref. There is also another group of 12 cairns and a wall to the NE at SD18780 98530, which have been given the same SMR No. There is no text information for the digital data, therefore exact details are impossible to give (S1065). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system, located on undulating ground north of Smallstone Beck 730m ENE of Birkerthwaite. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 40 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to lm high. The circular cairns measure between 2.2m and 6m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 2.7m and 8.8m long by 2.4m and 6.9m wide. The cairns are predominantly arranged in two groups: One group of ten is centred towards the north eastern end of the monument at approximately SD18789854. The larger group is centred towards the south western end of the monument at approximately SD18579835. Associated with this latter group of clearance cairns is a field system consisting of a small stone-walled enclosure about 13m in diameter, together with an alignment of clearance cairns, which are considered to represent the line of an old field boundary in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a fence or hedge. To the south west of this cairn alignment there is a cairn-free area considered to be the site of an old field plot. Elsewhere within the cairnfield there are other cairn-free areas which may also represent the sites of old fields (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield and Associated Field System W of the Knott

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. There is also a bield (a wall built to give shelter to sheep) of Post Medieval date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32865.

This is a group of clearance type cairns and a post-medieval shelter for stock on a uniform and moderately sloped area of well drained ground. It is a clearly defined piece of land; to the north and west it is edged by a sharp break of slope which drops away on to an expanse of bog, to the south and south-west it is edged by poor drainage and finally to the east there are the steep slopes leading up to The Knott. The cairns of this group are markedly larger and better defined than those of the other small cairnfields in this area; this may reflect that the land was better drained and there was therefore brash stone closer to the surface than in the boggy areas. Further information is available in the CLAU Site Catalogue (S1920). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system located on a gently sloping area of fellside 350m west of the summit of The Knott. It provides evidence for the prehistoric exploitation of this landscape and includes 39 oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 2.8m to 10.6m long by 2.1m to 6.3m wide and up to 0.7m high. The cairns are grouped into four small clusters, three of which are similar in being relatively large, prominent and well-defined, while the fourth group of cairns differs by being small, low-lying and relatively ill-defined. Within the cairnfield there is a small field or plot with boundaries defined by cairn alignments. The land within this field is predominantly stone-free, flat and well-drained and it is interpreted as a prehistoric field which was deliberately cleared of stone in order to render the ground usuable for agricultural cultivation or stock enclosure. Elsewhere some of the cairns at the northern and towards the southern end of the cairnfield form alignments oriented downslope which are interpreted as representing the lines of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a hedge or fence (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield and Associated Field System on Stainton Fell 330m S of the Knott

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32864.

These cairns are on a moderately sloped, but undulating hill-side adjacent to a large crag and associated scree. At SD1423094882 is a small section of dry stone wall and it is possibly just a small bield. The cairns are probably a result of stone clearance; they are generally small, low-lying and ill-defined. Some of the cairns have substantial amounts of stone material but none of them are prominent. There are two cairn alignments, which are both orientated downslope. They could possibly represent stone clearance along former field boundaries, which may imply there was a field in between; the possible bield is in between between the two alignments and appears to lie at the top of the possible 'field'. This is a small, simple and remote cairnfield like many of those from the Stainton Fell area (S1920). The monument includes a small prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system located on a moderately sloped area of undulating moorland on Stainton Fell 330m south of The Knott. It provides evidence for the prehistoric exploitation of this landscape and includes a short length of stone wall and 16 oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 2.2m to 6m long by 1.8m to 4.9m wide and up to 0.6m high. Some of the cairns form two alignments oriented downslope which are interpreted as representing the lines of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a hedge or fence. This field is approximately 25m-30m wide and its eastern boundary may have been formed by a short length of stone bank upslope of the cairn alignments (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield and Associated field system 760m NNE of Stainton

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and a field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32862.

A small group of cairns and a stone bank on a small area of well drained ground which is edged to the west by forestry, to the south by an area of bog and to the north by a modern field boundary. The stone bank is fairly uniform, displays signs of dry stone structure and may be a decayed wall. It follows the edge of an area of bog and may represent the edge of a small field. The cairns display substantial variations in size and form. One cairn (SD1341894935) is fairly large but has an open ended, rectilinear section removed from it. The section has straight, well defined internal edges which contrast with the ill-defined external edges of the cairn; it would appear to be a modern cut, possibly excavated by a JCB type excavator. There is an allignment of four irregular cairns which lies approximately parallel to the modern field boundary and could possibly represent stone clearance along the line of a former field boundary (S1920). The monument includes a small prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system located in a modern enclosure on Stainton Fell 760m NNE of Stainton. It provides evidence for the prehistoric exploitation of this landscape and includes a stone bank and a group of nine oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 3m to 11m long by 2.2m to 8.4m wide and up to 0.5m high. Some of the cairns along the northern edge of the cairfield form an alignment which is interpreted as representing the line of an old field boundary in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a hedge or fence. The southern boundary of this field is represented by the stone bank. A modern stone wall on the monument's western side is excluded from the scheduling althought the ground beneath it is included (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield on Stainton Fell SW of the Knott

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32863.

There are 3 distinct groups of cairns within this site. The first, centred at SD313625494940 is a group of six sites on a small island of moderately drained land, surrounded by a large expanse of bog. The cairns are low-lying and very ill-defined because of the vegetation growth around them. There is no indication of any cairns in the bog and it is probable that the drainage in this area has not changed significantly since the cairns were built. The second group (SD313820494890) comprises a group of clearance type cairns on an island of well drained land, surrounded by a large expanse of bog. The ground has a slight gradient and is covered by tussocky grass. The cairns are of all sizes and are generally ill-defined, partly because of the obscuring vegetation, but also because they are not particularly prominent. The distribution is essentially random; there are no obvious alignments and it is a classic small, primary type of cairnfield. There are no cairns within the poorly drained areas suggesting that the drainage has not changed significantly since the cairns were built. The third group are a small group of five cairns on a moderate sloped area of well-drained ground above an expansive area of bog (SD313910494980). The cairns are irregular in size and definition. They are associated with natural outcropping and some of them may be natural (S1920). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield located on gently sloping ground on Stainton Fell 540m south west of The Knott. It provides evidence for the prehistoric exploitation of this landscape and includes over 30 oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 2.4m to 9.1m long by 1.9m to 5.8m wide and up to 0.5m high. The cairns are distributed in two sub-groups, each on an island of well-drained land within a large expanse of moorland mire. The western group comprises 6 clearance cairns while the eastern group comprises 28 clearance cairns (S905)

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield, Associated Field System and Hut Circle E of Water Crag

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Prehistoric date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32878.

Some 31 cairns, situated on a gentle slope to the north of Devoke Water and ending 300 ft from the lake (S1361). See article by Leech 'Cairns in the Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 7-8). See note in the 1964 volume of C&WAAS by Cherry and Fletcher (S2211 p. 373) and the NMR Excavation Index 629377 for details of the excavation undertaken in 1961 see (S1347). There are 3 long cairns and 21 round cairns and 2 lengths of wall. The cairns extend over an area 130m E-W on the S facing slope of Water Crag overlooking Devoke Water, between the 270m and 240m contours. On the E part of the site is bracken, on the W there is dense heather. The walls are grass covered, earthwork banks and could form part of an enclosure (S1869 p. 15-23). The site is included in the Survey of Birkby and Birker Fells conducted by CLAU in 1982 (S1065). Note:This site together with SMR 2696 appear to be covered by by this scheduling, SAM 32878: The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of a prehistoric cairnfield, associated field system and a hut circle. It is located to the east of Water Crag, on the plateau between Water Crag and Rough Crag, extends downslope southwards towards Devoke Water, and represents evidence of the Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The prehistoric cairnfield is centred at approximately SD15629738 and includes over 120 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.7m high. The circular cairns measure between 2.2m to 6.9m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 3.4m to 9.1m long by 1.9m to 6.4m wide. The western extent of the cairnfield is marked by a short length of stone banking together with the crags below the summit of Water Crag. A field system associated with the cairnfield consists of a curvilinear enclosure centred at approximately SD15589726. Elsewhere within the cairnfield a number of cairn-free areas may indicate the former site of small field plots. On the north western side of the cairnfield, in a sheltered position at SD15489754, there is a platform containing the remains of a hut circle 4.7m in diameter. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. This clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield, Field System 630m East of the confluence of Hall Beck and Devoke Water

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and field systems (groups or complexes of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32886. This site is possibly the same as HER 31716.

Centred SD16459750. A group of 45 small cairns is situated to the SE of Rough Crag, and 510m to the E of the easternmost cairn of the group centred SD15689741. The cairns are on sloping ground, and are in 2 distinct groups separated by a flatter area of ground circa 50m wide by at least 140m in length. See plan (S1869 p. 16-18, S1361). Also see article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 12). The site is included in a survey of Birkby and Birker Fells undertaken by CLAU in 1982 and 1983 (S1065). The site can be seen on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). This seems to be the same as HER 31716. The monument includes the prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system located on the south-facing slopes of The Seat, 630m east of the confluence of Hall Beck and Devoke Water. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 30 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.4m high. The circular cairns measure between 1.8m to 5.9m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 3.3m to 8.3m long by 1.6m to 2.7m wide. Associated with the cairnfield is a field system consisting of two short lengths of stone wall or banks running downslope on a north west-south east alignment marking the north eastern and south western limits of the field system. Another feature of the field system, and one considered to be an indicator of past arable cultivation, is a lynchet running across the contours and centred at approximately SD16759675. A short length of drystone wall on the monument's south west side is excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath it is included (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield, Field System and Funerary Cairn 520m S of Barnscar Settlement

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32860.

A small cairnfield below a sharp craggy scarp, which separates it from the main part of the Barnscar settlement. At the bottom of the scarp there are large amounts of natural brash deposit however this decreases in quantity with distance away from the scarp. Some cairns are in association with some of the brash and are generally ill-defined as a result. The terrain of the main part of the cairnfield is gentle sloped and well-drained, however there is a break of slope below the eastern plot and there is an expansive area of bog at the bottom of it. To the west of a cairn at SD1334695499, there is a large area of uniform, stone-free ground which may have been improved at some stage, however there are no cairns or sites in association. The cairns are generally prominent and moderately defined, however there are variations in size. There is a possible plot defined at the top by a line of cairns extending from the bank at SD1338895463 and at the bottom by the alignment of cairns and banks. There is no evidence of any lynchets above or below the plot. Within the plot there are relatively few surface stones, it does however appear to be fairly bumpy but this may be because of the tussocky grass in the area. To the east of the same bank at SD1338895463, there is a further possible plot defined to the south by the alignment of cairns which are orientated towards the lower end of the bank. The cairn at SD1334695499 is a very large, but not particularly prominent mound, which appears to have been disturbed on the southern side. It is slightly remote from the main part of the cairn-group and it is considerably larger than the average cairn from Barnscar; there is a slight possibility that it was a funerary monument. The cairns are similar in prominence and form to those of the adjacent cairnfield (SMR No. 8733) and there is a possibility that the two cairn groups were broadly contemporary. Bracken cover obscures much of the area even during the spring season and this limits the ability to interpret the site (S1920). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, an associated field system and a funerary cairn located on partly-enclosed gently-sloping land 520m south of Barnscar settlement. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes a number of short lengths of stone bank and over 60 oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring between 2m to 7m long by 1.1m to 5.2m wide and up to 0.6m high. The cairns are divided into two groups separated by a 35m gap and are distinct in cairn size and concentration suggesting that they may be a product of different episodes of stone clearance. One group is located in the enclosed fields on the cairnfield's western side, the other group is located on the open fell on the cairnfield's eastern side. The associated prehistoric field system consists of two fields or plots, one being located in each of the two groups of clearance cairns. The fields are bounded by stone banks or cairn alignments which are interpreted as representing the line of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a fence or hedge. Both fields are relatively stone-free, flat and well-drained, and are interpreted as prehistoric fields which were deliberately cleared of stone in order to render the ground usable for agricultural cultivation. The prehistoric funerary cairn is located at SD13349549 and consists of a turf-covered oval-shaped mound of stones measuring 11.1m long by 10.7m wide and up to 0.4m high. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. This clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC. All modern field boundaries are excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath them is included (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield, Hut Circle Settlement, Field System, 290m SE Low Birker Tarn

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), hut circle settlement (a settlement consisting of several hut circles (round houses), either grouped together or dispersed) and an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32891.

Three short lengths of low walling, two of which may have formed part of an enclosure. Within the enclosure are 2 hut circles. Possibly associated with cairns (S1361). This site is also included in the Catalogue and Maps of Survey at Birkby Fell and Birker Fell West conducted by CLAU in 1983 (S1065). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, hut circle settlement and an associated field system, located on relatively flat ground 290m south east of Low Birker Tarn, immediately south of an unnamed stream which drains into Low Birker Pool. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes one oval-shaped and six circular clearance cairns up to 0.7m high. The circular cairns measure between 2.4m and 9m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairn measures 4m long by 2.7m wide. The hut circle settlement is centred towards the north eastern end of the monument at approximately SD19339941. It consists of the fragmentary stone walls of a sub-circular enclosure within which are the remains of two hut circles between 5m and 5.5m in diameter. One of the huts has an entrance on the western side while the other has an entrance on its north eastern side. Associated with the cairnfield and hut circle settlement are fragmentary traces of a small field system consisting of a curvilinear stone wall or bank which may have formed part of an enclosure, together with two short lengths of wall. The area between these features is relatively cairn-free suggesting that the ground was cleared in preparation for arable cultivation (S905). The site was recorded by Peter Rodgers in May 2002 when it was covered in dense bracken. He identified a hut circle with associated boundary walls (S1825).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield, Hut Circle Settlement, Field System, Shieling,etc on Birkby Fell

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), hut circle settlement (round houses indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of stone, which formed the base of the walls), field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) and funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) of Bronze Age date. There is also a shieling (pasture to which animals were driven for grazing, with an associated temporary hut for domestic or agricultural use) of Medieval date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32870.

A cairnfield centred at SD 152969. Most cairns are 3.6-9.2 m in diam, but one is 16.75 m across (S1361). See also HER 2696 which is scheduled as part of the same cairnfield, sites 013171-013455 in the County Index (S904). The Site is included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 376 (S1939). J. Cherry records 70 cairns at the W end of Devoke Water. These were marked on the OS map and were noted by Ward in CW1,3,251. The largest cairn was 55ft in diameter, the remainder being between 12 and 30ft. See article 'Cairns in the Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 7-8). Detailed survey in 1982 recorded the following: on a prominent, but low rise to the W of Devoke Water were 138 small cairns, two larger cairns, several lengths of walling and at least five structures. On the highest point of the low rise, and occupying a very prominent crest as seen from E or W, is a cairn 14.6m diameter with a stone kerb and having only one small cairn situated within a 40m radius. To the E were more small cairns, three hut circles, two rectangular structures and two approximately parallel walls one of which marked the approximate S limit of the group of cairns. To the W of the large round cairn were several straight alignments of groups of cairns. For the published plan and description see the CLAU Site Catalogue (S1065). Also see article 'Settlements a Groups of Small Cairns on Birkby and Birker Fells' by Leech in the 1983 volume of C&WAAS for site location and details (S1869 p. 15-23). See the NMR Excavation Index 1030158 for details of an excavation undertaken in 1985 by Wimble and Oliver (S1347). The site is mentioned in George & Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 50). The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of a prehistoric cairnfield within which is a hut circle settlement, consisting of the remains of three stone hut circles, an associated field system, a funerary cairn, and a medieval shieling. It is located on a prominent low rise on Birkby Fell to the west of Devoke Water and represents evidence of the Bronze Age and medieval exploitation of this landscape. The prehistoric cairnfield is centred at approximately SD15029690 and includes over 140 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.7m high. The circular cairns measure between lm to 7.8m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 4.3m to 13m long by 2.2m to 8m wide. Towards the south eastern end of the cairnfield, overlooking the western shore of Devoke Water, are the remains of the three stone hut cirles which collectively form the hut circle settlement. The southern of the three is built against a stone bank or wall and has an entrance in its eastern side, the western hut circle has an entrance in its north eastern side, whilst the entrance to the eastern hut circle is currently masked by tumble. A field system associated with the cairnfield and hut circle settlement is centred at approximately SD15039688 and consists of numerous short lengths of stone banking or wall and a number of cairn alignments which are interpreted as representing the line of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a fence or hedge. At SD15129689, at the highest point of the monument, there is a prehistoric funerary cairn measuring 14.7m in diameter and 0.9m high. The cairn is visible from a considerable distance and is defined by a stone kerb around its edge, but it has suffered minor disturbance by having a small modern shelter erected at its centre. Medieval use of this area is attested by the remains of a shieling centred at SD15189694. It consists of the lower courses of a single-roomed stone-walled rectangular structure measuring approximately 12m long by 7m wide with an entrance at the centre of its western side. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. The clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC (S905). Note that SMR 2696 now forms part of the scheduled monument no 32878.

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Cairnfield, ring cairn, hut circle and field system on Thwaites Fell

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), ring cairn (a low, wide, circular ring or bank of stones surrounding an open, roughly circular area which is (or was initially) free of cairn material), hut circle (a round house indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) and an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Prehistoric date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 35013.

A great many small mounds and heaps of stone. See the NAS 1975 gazetteer (S1323). According to Clare, some have been dug, and the hillside is rutted with old paths and trackways - site no. 440 (S1939). According to OS (31.5.1989), a group of cairns on the NE slope of a fell, near the junction of two coach-roads, one leading from Duddon Bridge to Bootle, were examined in Sept 1927. Three were excavated and measured 15 x 10 ft, 211/2 x 15 ft, and 28 x 16 ft, respectively, the former being the nearest to the N. All had a revetment of large stones enclosing a cobble flooring. In the largest there was a small cist and several holes about 18" above the floor. Nothing was found to date the cairns (S1361). This site is included in the Thwaites Fell archaeological survey, undertaken in 1984 and 1992 as part of the Lake District National Park Survey by CLAU. A large number of clearance cairns, mostly in poor condition and ill-defined. Sections of stone bank can also be found, but these are irregularly defined. The bield within this group is HER 31032 and the ring cairn is 31033 (S1916). The scheduled monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, ring cairn, hut circle and field system. It is located on the east facing gently-sloping fellside north of a minor road across Corney Fell and represents Bronze Age exploitation of the landscape. The cairnfield consists of over 200 round and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high; the round cairns measuring between 2m - 6.6m in diameter, the oval-shaped cairns measuring between 3.3m - 9.5m long by 1.9m - 6m wide. At SD1766 8972 there is a ring cairn consisting of a well-defined circle of stones 8.25m in diameter and up to 0.3m high surrounding a flattish, largely stone-free centre. At SD1731 8993 there are the remains of a hut circle (SMR No. 31031). Associated with these features are faint traces of a field system formed by fragments of enclosures and stone banks or walls. At SD1744 8998 there are the southern and eastern walls of a small enclosure, while further south at SD1754 8985, there is a discontinuous stone bank defining the western and northern boundaries of a probable D-shaped enclosure devoid of cairns. A third, smaller three sided enclosure is situated at SD1762 8975. Three lengths of stone bank or wall are found close to the southern end of the cairnfield; one about 70m long marks the southern limit of the cairnfield while another, about 20m long and well-defined, lies beyond the south western limit of the cairnfield (S905). For details of archaeological investigation at the site see the NMR excavation index 629361 (S1347). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the Cumbria County Council SMR (S917). Site recorded by The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record. The site includes 195 sites, which are predominantly clearance cairns. There are also the remains of walling, an enclosure and a single ring cairn. The Trust database entry largely summarises the previous survey and scheduling work carried out (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric Enclosure, Cairns SW of Boat How

ns:description.ns:full:
An enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier) and cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Prehistoric date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 23698.

The monument includes a prehistoric enclosure containing ten clearance cairns. It is located on a relatively flat area of open fellside to the southwest of Boat How and lies within a large area of open moorland known as Burnmoor which contains an abundance of prehistoric remains. The enclosure has a boundary on its north and east sides formed by a wall or stone bank measuring up to 4.7m wide and 0.4m high and fragmented into six separate lengths. There is an entrance on the eastern side leading into an enclosed area of approx 0.75ha. In the western side of the enclosure there are ten clearance cairns ranging from 2.15m - 3.85m in diameter and 0.1m - 0.3m in height. The Boat How site survives reasonably well and is a good example of this class of monument. This monument contains a developed type of cairnfield; that is one where the land has been subjected to initial land clearance then utilised further, in this case by the construction of the enclosure. It contrasts markedly with the primary type of cairnfield found elsewhere on Burnmoor and illustrates well the differing prehistoric land management strategies. This monument lies close to other prehistoric monuments on Burnmoor and indicates the importance of this area in prehistoric times. Scheduling includes a 2m boundary around the archaeological features, considered to be essential for the monument's support and preservation (S905). The wall of the enclosure is in a fair condition, but poorly defined with stones protruding. The 10 cairns associated with the enclosure are generally in a poor condition and ill-defined (S1914). Site mentioned in LUAU archaeological survey 2000, but no new information given (S1892). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record (S2873). The site is also recorded by H A W Burl for a settlement, possibly Bronze Age, with many clearance cairns, at least twenty hut circles and a possible droveway, noted in 1947 (S1028). Included in Regional Archaeological Audit (S5350).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system north of Pike How, 650m west of High Ground

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32882.

A possible settlement consisting of 2 enclosures, 3 cairns, and 5 lengths of walling is situated on the N side of Pike How. The largest of the enclosures is roughly circular, ca 50 metres diam, with the enclousre wall rarely surviving more than 1 metre in height. The smaller enclosure is roughly oval in plan, measuring 20 x 30 metres. See article on the survey of settlements and groups of Cairns in 1982 by Leech in the 1983 volume of C&WAAS (S1869 p. 16). (S1869 p. 18). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system located on the northern slopes of Pike How, 650m west. of High Ground. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The cairnfield includes three circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns measuring up to 0.5m high. The circular cairns measure between 5.5m to 5.9m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairn measures 5.5m long by 4.4m wide. The field system associated with the cairnfield includes two sub-circular stone-walled enclosures; the larger is approximately 50m in diameter, the smaller is roughly oval in plan and measures about 20m by 30m. Nearby are six lengths of stone wall or bank considered to be old field boundaries. Five of these banks run downslope and one runs across the slope virtually following the contour (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Prehistoric cairnfield and enclosure 750m west of Barnscar settlement

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), stock enclosure (a pound for the accommodation of livestock) and a bank (linear or curvilinear construction of stone) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32858.

Cairns and a possible hut circle recorded here. See Crawford and George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 47). The CLAU Survey identified a fairly compact but substantial cairnfield, on a uniform, gentle gradient. The ground is well drained but there is a break of slope marking the eastern edge of the cairnfield and at the bottom of this the terrain is very poorly drained. The cairnfield is within a large, post-enclosure field however the land has not been improved. The cairns are moderately prominent, with regular rounded profiles; some of them are very prominent . However there is very thick, dense matt grass cover in the area of the cairnfield and there are only occasional stones protruding through the vegetation cover. It also has the effect of making the cairns very ill-defined and a lot of them have been drawn with dashed lines as a result. There is a partial enclosure, which has a slightly sunken interior and was possibly a small structure (SD1251695741, now SMR No. 31061). In the middle of the cairnfield there is a stone, stock feeding trough, it is safe to assume that it post dates the cairnfield. There are no significant alignments and it would appear to be a typical primary type of cairnfield (S1920). Also see article 'Plotting of Archaeological Sites from Vertical aerial Photographs: An Interim Report' by V.E. Turner in the 1984 volume of C&WAAS (S1868 p. 270-274). The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield and associated enclosure (for enclosure see SMR 31061) located on gently-sloping ground 750m west of Barnscar settlement. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes five short lengths of stone bank, 49 oval-shaped clearance cairns and a small, ovalshaped stock enclosure with an entrance on the north western side and a slightly sunken interior. The clearance cairns measure between 1.5m to 6m long by lm to 5m wide and up to 1.1m high. Pollen cores taken from the sediments of nearby Devoke Water have revealed the changing vegetational history of this area over the last 5,000 years and show episodes of forest clearance and a development of grassland during the prehistoric period. During one of these episodes most trees were cut down and were soon replaced by extensive grassland. This clearance is associated with the Bronze Age on the basis of its similarity to a clearance episode from Seathwaite Tarn 9km to the east, which has been scientifically dated to around 1000 BC (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Ring Cairn and Cairns on Heathwaite Fell

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), ring cairn (a low, wide, circular ring or bank of stones surrounding an open, roughly circular area which is (or was initially) free of cairn material) and hut circle settlement (round houses indicated by the presence of a low, roughly circular bank of turf, earth or stone, which formed the base of the walls) of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34990.

An isolated cairn in poor condition (S1361). Scheduled as SAM 90o. It appears to have been badly robbed and is 6 m x 0.3 m high. No traces of a ditch or retaining circle. According to OS it is "possibly sepulchral." See 2160 and 3210 for details. AM County Index notes that area between this and 90m (SMR 4932) totally devoid of any associated features (S904). See maps in SMR envelope 2160. After surveying the area, CLAU identified a small group of cairns, circular platforms and a possible ring cairn on rocky undulating ground.The prominent ring feature is possibly a ring cairn, but alternatively may be a disturbed round cairn as the internal edge is slightly irregular and not particularly well defined. The cairns are generally very small, ill-defined and associated with natural outcropping. However a cairn at SD2548786860 is moderately defined, and is clearly artificial and therefore lends credibility to the rest of the cairns. These are not associated with any cultivation (R&F) and are on poor agricultural ground. There is thus a possibility that they are prehistoric. They are located on top of a small natural col. The circular platforms are located on a steep northerly facing slope and are similar in form to those of SMR No. 2167. 2 sites are very poorly defined and very small; the only reasonable example is at grid ref. SD2544386848, which has a moderately defined, oval shaped, central platform and is clearly artificial. The other sites appear to be too small to have held a hut, however this one is adequately sized.The boggy area may have once been a small tarn in the prehistoric period and in which case these platforms would have been close to the shore. However they are north facing and would not have been protected from west to north-easterly winds (S1922). Forming part of SAM 34990/02 with smr no. 4932. A small prehistoric hut circle settlement consisting of 3 circular platforms between 2m - 4m in diameter terraced into the hillslope. A sunken circular hollow considered to be the site of an isolated hut about 120m south west of the three platforms, a small cairnfield and a funerary cairn (S905). The site is visible on aerial photographs in the Cumbria County Council collection (S917).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Rospow Hills Prehistoric Cairnfield & Associated Field System, Caldbeck

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34959.

Site comprises 14 round cairns, 5 long cairns, 10 linear features, and one triangular mound, although some of these features are dubious. The site is situated to the W (upslope) of site 8387, at the foot of the steeper area of the fell. A sketch plan published in 1934 shows far more cairns than are now seen to exist, probably due to the inclusion of natural rockoutcrops. Description of the detailed elements can be found in the CLAU Site Catalogue (S1923). Also see article 'Results of Survey Work carried out on the Caldbeck Fells' by V.E. Turner in the 1987 volume of C&WAAS (S1865 p. 19-25). See article 'Tumuli near Carrock Fell' by M.Barker in the 1934 volume of C&WAAS (S1910 p. 107) and the 'Report of the Committee for 1933-1935 of Prehistoric Studies' in the 1935 volume of C&WAAS (S1908 p. 174). Also see articles 'Excavations in Carrock Fell' in the 1950 volume of C&WAAS (S1909 p. 201-202). The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of Rospow Hills prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system 740m south west of High Wath Ford. It is located on gently sloping fellside on the northern lower slopes of Carrock Fell and represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The cairnfield consists of 20 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.4m high; the circular cairns measure between 3.6m to 7m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 7.5m to 13m long by 3.lm to 5.7m wide. The associated field system consists of nine short lengths of stone bank, most of which have returns, suggesting that they formed two sides of small field plots. Amongst the stone banks in the eastern half of the monument are cairn alignments which are interpreted as representing the line of old field boundaries in which sporadic patches of stone clearance were piled against a fence or hedge. A modern bield is excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath it is included (S905). For details of archaeological investigation at this site see the NMR excavation index 645794, 645793 (S1347).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Rough Crag prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system 600m ENE of Woodend Bridge

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) and an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34967. This site is the same as HER 1411.

The monument includes Rough Crag prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system 600m ENE of Woodend Bridge. It is located on two natural terraces on the steeply sloping west-facing slope of Rough Crag and represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape. The cairnfield includes 13 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0. 8m high. The circular cairns measure between 1. 9m and 4m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between'2.9m and 8.5m long by 1.6m and 6.6m wide The associated field system consists of a small rectangular stone-walled enclosure at the northern end of the monument. This enclosure uses the base of a crag as its eastern wall. A short distance to the south of the enclosure there is a low stone wall running approximately parallel with and close to the base of the crag for about 25m; faint traces of returns at either end of the wall suggest that this feature was also an enclosure (S905). This site falls within HER 1411 see this record for further details.

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument
