ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Rough Crag prehistoric cairnfield, funerary cairn and a linear boundary 1000m ENE of Woodend Bridge

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) and linear boundary of Prehistoric date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34968.

At the top of a S facing slope is a large oval cairn 12.3 x 15.4 m with the remains of a stone kerb. Evidence of excavation in the centre. Down the slope to the S are many small circular cairns, 3-5 m in diam. Many have been disturbed. Short stretches of tumbled walling also visible (S1361, S1116 p. 47). See volume III of C&WAAS (S2341 p. 251). This site is also included in T. Clare's MA thesis as site no. 384 (S1939). For more details see AM County Index (S904) and the CLAU 1982 and 1983 survey of the area (S1065). Rough Crag prehistoric cairnfield, funerary cairn and linear boundary 1000m ENE of Woodend Bridge, survives well and forms part of a well-preserved prehistoric landscape extending along the fellsides of south west Cumbria. In conjunction with a wide range of other prehistoric remains in the vicinity the monument represents evidence of long term management and exploitation of this area in prehistoric.times (S905). Note: Scheduled Monument Number 34967 is also included within this area. The monument includes Rough Crag prehistoric cairnfield and associated field system 600m ENE of Woodend Bridge. Site recorded within The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record as a Bronze Age D shaped enclosure with associated large cairnfield situated on the fell side of Hesk Fell (S2873). The entry records the site within a gently sloping bowl with areas of adjacent mire and streams. The main body of the site is across the higher, better drained ground around the bowl. Cairns are scattered around the enclosure only. Archaeological survey work suggests that the enclosure and cairnfield are contemporary. This work has identified approximately 61 cairns (20011*13-14, *16a-33, *34b-43b, *49-78), one ring feature (20011*15), one bank (20011*34a), walls (20011*44- 45), enclosures (20011*46b & 20011*46e) and two huts (20011*46c- 46d); the remains are divided into four sub-groups which are detailed in the entry (S2873). (LUAU, 1992: Group No: PRN 9486). Part of the area lies on Pikeside farm, part on Baskell Farm (Claris, P.D. 1983). Actually the site lies solely in Baskell Farm (Siddall, J.A. 1998), (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Settlement and Cairns on Heathwaite Fell

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) including a possible funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) of Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34990.

9 cairns with diameters varying from 3.5-6m, with a maximum height of 0-5 m. Scheduled as SAM 90t (S904). Composed of loose stones with some earthfast boulders. No traces of kerbs or ditches. Some of the cairns in the S part of the group appear to be elongated (8 m long 3.5 m wide, 0.7 m high). OS Index states "more cairns in the vicinity than the number published, and these, together with the intervening "plots" form an obvious pattern of stone clearance" (S1361). See articles by Charles M Jopling (S2595 p.448-453) and Swainson Cowper (S2269) in different Archaeologia's. See article 'Prehistory of Cumberland and Westmorland' in the 1933 volume of C&WAAS (S2219 p. 172). These may be those located by Clare in 1972 (465) which he centres on SD257879, mounds and cairns on a NW facing slope. At SD25618776 he located a low mound, the S half of which has been destroyed. The mound can be seen to to composed of small stones. Larger stones on the N circumference appear to be remains of a kerb. As the site overlooks site 464, it could be Evans second circle (S1939). See HER 3544 and maps in HER 2160 envelope. The area of this cairnfield is generally flat although it is on the edge of a tarn. It is well drained ground and it has only small amounts of bracken cover.Three cairns are separated from the rest of the group by a natural break of slope, and they are on a high level terrace by comparison with the adjacent area. However the type of land above and below this break of slope are fairly similar. The cairns of this group are regular, well defined, and slightly prominent. They appear to be genuine cairns and this would appear to be an area that was cleared of stone for agriculture. It is one of the best cairn groups in this northern part of Heathwaite Fell. The group to the north of the track is particularly distinctive; they form a tight cluster, and they are large and regular (S1922). A small group of clearance cairns, a length of stone bank and a circular well-defined prominent mound with a central depression, which is considered to be a funerary cairn (S905). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the Cumbria County Council collection (S917).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Settlement and Cairns on Heathwaite Fell and Giants Graves

ns:description.ns:full:
Two possible ring cairns (a low, wide, circular ring or bank of stones surrounding an open, roughly circular area which is (or was initially) free of cairn material) within a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Scheduled as SAM 90b. Two ring cairns excavated spring, 1842. Charred bones covered by thin, flat stone in centre of northernmost; charrred bones and fragments of a stone ring in centre of southernmost. The Giants Grave (N cairn) consists of a circular enclosure, overall diam 8 m, bounded by a stoney bank with an average width of 2 m and max height of o.3 m. The core of the bank consists of large stones, some of which appear to have been set on edge. One, called the "headstone", is 0.8 m wide , 0.2 m thick, 1 m high. No trace of an outer didth. S cairn is 6 m diam, 0.3 m high, has possible kerb. The N cairn may be Evans. See also SMR 2163 (S904, S1361and see 'Furness and Furness Abbey' by F. Evans in 1842 (S2411 p. 114-115)). A long barrow, 15 feet long, is the Giant's Grave at Heathwaite, Woodland. See the 1933 volume of C&WAAS (S2219 p. 172). See T. Clare's MA thesis site no. 464 (S1939). This is a widely dispersed group of cairns, including Giants Graves, which appears to be a ring cairn with a standing stone at the north-west end (SD2563087964, further information can be found under SMR No. 31066). At SD2557988034, there is a slightly prominent, circular bank, which could be a possible ring cairn (this is now SMR No. 31067).There are 13 other cairns which are not particularly well defined or prominent, but appear to be consistent with stone clearance type cairns (S1922). With revised scheduling (16/10/2002), only the two funerary cairns (SMR No.s 31066 and 31067) have been scheduled SAM No.s 34990/08 and 09 (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Settlement and Cairns on Heathwaite Fell, Kirkby Ireleth

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

Alleged cairns or stone clearance heaps. Reports vary as to the number, from 3 to 9 cairns, varying in diam from 3-3.5 m, max height 0.3 m. The mounds consist of large stones protruding from the vegetation cover. No traces of kerbs or ditches. See also maps in HER 2160 envelope (S1361). Recorded on OS 2nd Edition 6" map (S2081). See the NAS 1975 Gazetteer (S1323). A small group of cairns which are in an area with occasional outcrop. Most of them have frost fracturing on the component stones indicating that they have been exposed, in situ for a long time. There is a possibility that they are all natural. There is less bracken cover on the sites by comparison with HER 9403 but there is considerably more outcropping around. The sites are on a fairly gentle gradient (S1922).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Smallstone Beck prehistoric cairnfield 410m east of Birkerthwaite

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 32889.

A group of 20 cairns is situated S of Smallstone Beck between the 240 and 250 m contours. Three of the cairns are separated from the main group. See article 'Cairns in Birker Fell and Ulpha Fell Area' by J. Cherry in the 1961 volume of C&WAAS (S2085 p. 9). At this grid ref. the CLAU digital data has shown there are 6 cairns and a possible enclosure (SAM 32889). Further east at SD1880 9819, south of Smallstone Beck is a group of c. 21 cairns (SAM 32888). This could correspond to this HER record. There is no text information for this data, therefore exact details cannot be given. The same HER No. has been given to the group of cairns to the east (S1065). The site is included in Crawford's Archaeological Survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 50). Some of the cairns appear to be scheduled under SAM 32889: The monument includes Smallstone Beck prehistoric cairnfield, located on relatively flat ground a short distance south of Smallstone Beck, 410m east of Birkerthwaite. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes one oval-shaped and five circular clearance cairns up to 0.6m high. The circular cairns measure between 2.1m and 4.5m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairn measures 5.8m long by 4.3m wide (S905). The site is visible on aerial photographs from the CLAU collection (S923). See also SAM 32888 for the group to the east: The monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, located on a north-facing slope below a line of low crags 840m east of Birkerthwaite. It represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and includes over 20 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.7m high. The circular cairns measure between 3.5m and 6.6m long by 2.3m to 5m wide (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Cairnfield of (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) Bronze Age date. Included within Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 35013.

Site identified from vertical aerial photographs taken as part of the CLAU VAP Project in 1983 and field observation undertaken 20 April 1983. The site is comprised of an extensive cairnfield having approx 50 cairns which are widely spread across the fell. Some walls and possible hut circles are visible, but are in very poor condition. The cairns do not survive well. The cairnfield apparently continues further S, as HER 1465, and possibly as HER 3978. No obvious breaks in very extensive cairnfield (S1069). Also see article 'Plotting of Archaeological Sites from Vertical aerial Photographs: An Interim Report' by V.E. Turner in the 1984 volume of C&WAAS (S1868 p. 270-274). The area of the cairnfield on GIS has been enlarged to incorporate data from the CLAU Survey in 1984. Many clearance cairns were identified over a large area, mostly in poor condition and ill-defined (S1916). The scheduled monument includes a prehistoric cairnfield, ring cairn, hut circle and field system. It is located on the east facing gently-sloping fellside north of a minor road across Corney Fell and represents Bronze Age exploitation of the landscape. The cairnfield consists of over 200 round and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high; the round cairns measuring between 2m - 6.6m in diameter, the oval-shaped cairns measuring between 3.3m - 9.5m long by 1.9m - 6m wide. At SD1766 8972 there is a ring cairn consisting of a well-defined circle of stones 8.25m in diameter and up to 0.3m high surrounding a flattish, largely stone-free centre. At SD1731 8993 there are the remains of a hut circle (SMR No. 31031). Associated with these features are faint traces of a field system formed by fragments of enclosures and stone banks or walls. At SD1744 8998 there are the southern and eastern walls of a small enclosure, while further south at SD1754 8985, there is a discontinuous stone bank defining the western and northern boundaries of a probable D-shaped enclosure devoid of cairns. A third, smaller three sided enclosure is situated at SD1762 8975. Three lengths of stone bank or wall are found close to the southern end of the cairnfield; one about 70m long marks the southern limit of the cairnfield while another, about 20m long and well-defined, lies beyond the south western limit of the cairnfield (S905). Site recorded in The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:appellation.ns:name: Two Round Cairns 415m & 420m NNE of the Cockpit, Barton

ns:description.ns:full:
Two round cairns (a roughly hemispherical mound constructed primarily of stones, normally containing or covering one or more human burials. One of the mounds is partly surrounded and retained by a low stone kerb) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 22522.

A mound surrounded by humps and hollows, has a large hollow at its centre. See T.Clare's MA thesis site no. 135 (S1939). There appears to be another smaller mound adjacent to it (S2596). See S917. See also SMR 2756,2938-2941,2943 for possible related sites. Also SMR 2945. The monument includes two round cairns located on Moor Divock 415m and 420m NNE of The Cockpit stone circle. It includes a larger, oval mound of partly turf covered stones up to 0.3m high with max dimensions of 10.6m x 9.5m. There are some irregularly shaped surface hollows on the western side of this cairn. Immediately to the east is a smaller, slightly oval mound of partly turf coveredstones up to 0.25m high with max dimensions of 4.6m x 4.4m. The eastern edge of this smaller cairn is kerbed. Also included is the archaeologically sensitive area between the cairns. Despite surface disturbance the two round cairns survive reasonably well. The monument lies within an area of open fell rich in prehistoric monuments and will contain undisturbed archaeological deposits within the mounds and upon the old land surface beneath. Additionally, it lies at the western end of an alignment of funerary monuments stretching for over 1.5 km along the natural communication route over a col between the Lowther and Ullswater Valliys. It thus indicates the importance of this area in prehistoric times and the diversity of monument types to be found here. The monument will contribute to the study of the ceremonial function of cairns and other spatially associated monuments in the area. Scheduling includes a 2 metre boundary around the archaeological features considered to be essential for the monument's support and preservation (S905). LUAU Survey (No.s 101 - 107, Plan No. 5): a series of cairns and stone banks on the northern and southern sides of the modern track. Each individual feature has been surveyed, details are in the Askham Fell survey catalogue (S84).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
A cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

A group of 20 cairns recorded here. According to OS (31.5.89) 56 cairns were located on a W facing slope of moorland pasture above an area of bog. All are ill-formed heaps of stones varying in diam from 3-7m and some almost merge to form continuous banks. They appear to be the result of stone clearance, although no formal agricultural system survives and only small pockets of clearance are evident (S1361). This site is also included in Crawford and George's archaeological survey of Copeland (S1116 p. 52).

Monument Type: Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) an associated field system (a group or complex of fields which appear to form a coherent whole) and a funerary cairn (a stony mound containing or concealing deliberately deposited human remains) of Bronze Age date. Scheduled Ancient Monument no. 34958.

Site comprises a field system of banks, lynchets, and cairns. It is very subtle, although clearly visible in low, oblique, sunlight. Description of detailed features is available in the CLAU Site Catalogue (S1923). Also see article 'Results of Survey Work carried out on the Caldbeck Fells' by V.E. Turner in the 1987 volume of C&WAAS (S1865 p. 19-25). The scheduled area includes the following: The monument includes the earthworks and buried remains of Weasel Hills prehistoric cairnfield, associated field system, hut circle and funerary cairn immediately north and north west of High Wath Ford. It is located on gently sloping ground on Caldbeck Common and lies either side of the minor road between Mungrisedale and Caldbeck. The monument represents Bronze Age exploitation of this landscape and is sub-divided into two separate areas of protection. The prehistoric cairnfield is centred at approximately NY34733535 and consists of over 60 circular and oval-shaped clearance cairns up to 0.6m high. The circular cairns measure between 2.8m to 7.5m in diameter while the oval-shaped cairns measure between 2.8m to 16.5m long by 1.2m to 8.9m wide. A field system associated with the cairnfield lies either side of the minor road. To the west of the road the field system consists of a large horseshoe-shaped enclosure, centred at NY34683552, which is open on its south side and includes numerous lengths of stone bank which may have formed field boundaries, and two lynchets. To the east of the road the field system consists of a small horseshoe-shaped enclosure, three parallel lengths of stone wall each about 130m apart running downhill, and a number of short lengths of stone banks and lynchets running across the hillslope. At NY34643635 there are the remains of a hut circle about 7m in diameter, while at the eastern edge of the monument at NY35073536 there is an oval-shaped funerary cairn measuring llm north-south by 10m east-west and up to 1.lm high on its downslope east side. All modern field boundaries and the surfaces of all modern tracks are excluded from the scheduling, although the ground beneath these features is included (S905).

Monument Type: Monument

Monument Status: Scheduled Monument

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) of Bronze Age date.

LUAU Survey nos 496 - 551. A cairnfield divided into three sub-groups. For details of each feature see LUAU survey (S1564). Cairns and other components individually recorded by The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record. Unknown ring features are recorded with the numbers 21433, 21436, 21437, 21441, 21442, 21443, 21444, 21446, 21447, 21451, 21454, 21459, 21460, 21462 and 21466. Included in the site are possible prehistoric and Medieval banks numbers 21458, and 21427, 21431 and 21456 respectively. The site also includes features, such as a lynchet, that might have prehistoric antecedents (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument
ns:description.ns:summary: <b>Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns ...

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of cairns (monuments featuring a bank or mound constructed primarily of stone) of unknown date.

LUAU Survey nos 496 - 551 A well-scattered group of cairns on the edge of a gentle, moderately sloped ridge. The ground on the tops and sides of the ridge is well-drained, but a Y-shaped stock bield is in an area of mire at the foot of the ridge. The cairns are generally uniform in size (about 2-3m across). They have rounded profiles and include medium to large stones. For details of individual features see LUAU report (S1564). Site recorded within The National Trust Sites and Monuments Record. The individual component banks and cairns of the cairnfield have been recorded by The National Trust (S2873).

Monument Type: Monument
ns:description.ns:summary: <b>Site of cairns (monuments featuring a bank or ...

ns:address.ns:streetaddress: Murley Moss, Oxenholme Road, Kendal, Cumbria,

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other) which includes a round cairn (a roughly hemispherical mound constructed primarily of stones, normally containing or covering one or more human burials. The mound may be surrounded and partly retained by a low stone kerb) of Bronze Age date.

LUAU Survey nos 665 - 672 A small cairnfield on uniform sloped, unimproved ground which is not particularly well-drained. At the eastern side of the group is a line of three large cairns which are well-defined and prominent. The most prominent one is LUAU 671 which has a well-defined external bank, which appears to be distinct from the mound that appears to cap it. There are a few very large stones in the middle of it. It has the appearance of a funerary cairn, however it does not significantly stand out in form from some of the other cairns of the group which are also large and contain substantial amounts of stone. The cairns are on an area of gentle to moderately sloped land on the side of the Stare Beck gully; it is not a prominent location; there are more prominent locations nearby. For details of each individual feature, see details in LUAU report (S1564). location; there are more prominent locations nearby.

ns:description.ns:full:
Site of a cairnfield (a group of cairns occurring within close proximity to each other), banks (linear or curvilinear constructions of earth, turf and stone, often, but not always accompanied by a ditch), ring cairns (low, wide, circular rings or banks of stones surrounding an open, roughly circular area which is (or was initially) free of cairn material. The inner and outer faces of the bank may be kerbed) and an enclosure (an area of land enclosed by a boundary ditch, bank, wall, palisade or other similar barrier) of Bronze Age date.

A field system visible on aerial photographs from the Cumbria County Council collection (S917). CLAU survey nos. 1 - 14, 17-436, 689, 691-695. This is a large area of cairns, stone banks, ring cairns and other features - in all at least 422 components. For details of each cairn and sub-groupings of component sites, see the 1989 LUAU survey report for Whin Garth (S1564). No. 1 is a large oval enclosure edged by a prominent outer bank. It is well defined on the outside but less well-defined on the inside; there is no evidence of dry-stone structure [Size: length 30m, width 1 6m, height 0.45m, width of bank 3.6m]. J Quartermaine suggests the following sequence of events for this area: Initially an area of moorland was partially improved and clearance stone was put into piles; a simple and poorly defined field system was established. This work was undertaken on a seasonal base and the farmers lived in summer huts (shielings). This led to a permanent settlement (Scale Farm) and the cleared land was enclosed. Subsequently a second farm (between Guards or Guards End) which acquired and enclosed some of the Scale Farm land. The land on both sides of the phase three walls was cultivated. Finally a new field system was established which largely superceded the old; all its gates provided access onto the top lonning, suggesting that the Scale Farm had been abandoned at this time. There is no evidence of an enclosing bank around the western side. Survey No. 206 has a separate HER which is 30997, 219 is 30998, 283 is 30999, 335 is 31000 and 339 is 31001. There are areas of ridge and furrow within this field system, encompassed under HER 8761. Also see the RCHME publication 'Shielings and Bastles' (S1388).
